div.head: THE ETHIOPIAN RAILWAY QUESTION.
div.p: According to a report which appears in the "Debats" the difficulties regarding the Ethiopian Railway have now been practically arranged. The Paris journal states that the Negus is now ready to give his support to the completion of the line on condition that the enterprise will cease to have anything in common with the management or methods of the company at present in liquidation. It suggests that the Prench Government should guarantee the enterprise as the only sure means of bringing it to a successful issue.

The Débats considers that the main interest of France in the Ethiopian question lies in the completion and working of the railway from Jibuti to Addis Abeba. Certain financial interests endeavoured, it says, to secure international control of the railway by inculcating the opinion in France that England would not tolerate a French company and by giving the impression in England that public opinion and the Government in France were disposed to allow a company nominally international but practically English to take possession of a line which is destined to make Jibuti the outlet of all Southern Ethiopia. In order to inspire the French public with the necessary resignation, it was stated that Menelek was also desirous of giving the matter an international character. This network of intrigue, as the Débats describes it, was first broken through by the treaty of December 13, 1906, which formally recognized the French character of the line from Jibuti to Addis Abeba. After this fact had been estabished it was possible for the French envoy to remove the opposition of the Negus; who could entertain no mistrust of France unless it were systematically inspired by persons whose situation at Addis Abeba gave rise to the belief that they were supporters of French interests.

div.head: Police Budget
div.p: The report for the last 24 hour gives the following figurer: 12 thefts, 17 misdemeanour, and 64 petty offences.

div.head: Attempt suicide
div.p: A member of the police for stationed at Shibin al Kom, took a strong dose of opium owing to the refusal of his parents to advance him the funds to marry. Fortunately succour was at hand and his rash attempt has proved futile.

div.head: Chezireth Palace Fatality.
div.p: The manager of the Ghezireh Palace Hotel has recquested us to state that the case of the ghafir Ibrahim Ismail at Ghezireh was erroneously reported by the press. It transpires that the death of the ghaffir in question was not due to the collapse of a roof at the hotel but to the fall of a piece of wood which mortally struck the man, and which occurred at the so-called "Harem" which is in course of being pulled down.

div.head: Princesa Toussoun Fined
div.p: At Leeds last week Princess Toussoun, of Cambria House, Elsworthy road, Hampstead, was summoned for having driven motor at an excessive speed at Chapeltown, on September 1. The car was driven by the Princess, and contained another lady and the chauffeur, and the spped was alleged to have been twenty-five miles an hour. The Princess when charged with travelling at this speed, expressed her sorrow if it were true. She expressed the opinion that she was not going at the speed stated. They were, she said, going to catch a train. A fine of £3 and costs was imposed.

div.head: The American cotton crop
div.p: The United States Department of Agriculture last week issued its monthly report on the condition of the cotton crop, in which it states that the average condition on the 25th ultimo, taking the entire country, was 7.27, against 75.0 a month ago 77.3 last year, and a ten years' average of 74.5. The condition of Texas, the most important state, has deteriorated 8 points, and at 67 shows the worst condition since September, 1902, at 53 and 1901 at 56. Decreases of 4 points are shown in Florida and the Indian Territory, 3 points in Arkanss and Tennessee, and 2 points in Lousiana and Oklahoma, while in Georgia there is no change in the condition on the month. South Carolina shows an improvement of 2 points and North Carolina an improvement of 3 points.

div.head: MANSOURAH STONING CASE.
div.p: The statements published in the Press rê the recent stoning of Jews attending a funeral at Mansourah, are of a very grave character. The disturbance appears to have been absolutely unprovoked by the victims of a cowardly act of aggression and if the version published by some of our contemporaries is accurate, the police officer showed a curious conception of his duties when he released of the ringlenders in the distance without apparently taking their names. The incident is an interesting commentary on the statement of some of our contemporaries that there is no such thing as religious fanaticism in Egypt, for it is difficult to ascribe this act to any other cause, knowing as we do the peaceful and quiet character of the Jewish communities in this country. There is in our opinion no reason whatever to believe that such a spirit of religious animosity is generally diffused in the country but we hold, as we have always held, that there are sections of the population, composed we gladly admit, in most cases of its lees and scum, which cherish a violent hostility towards creeds other than their own, and are ready to manifest this hostility whenever the occasion seems suitable. Such sections of the population are sources of danger in view of the constant efforts made by certain journalists to inflame the passions of racial and religious hatred and furnish a standing dementi to the motto of "Hospitable to all" which adorns the English organ of one of the chief of these scribes, whose propaganda, perhaps without intention, has always seemed to us most calculated to use outbreaks of hostility between the various elements of the population of Egypt. We hope that the Nationalist Press will condemn in suitable language the action of the rioters at Mansourah. Otherwise we shall be able to estimate at their true worth their professions of tolerance and disclaimers of anything approaching religious hostility

div.head: THE "OLIVEMOOR."
div.p: We have this morning but little authentic news to give concerning the situation of the "Olivemoor," which appears to us to be as favourable as ever. Though salvage operations were commenced last Tuesday the position of the vessel is to-day practically the same as last week. We are officially informed that, given two days of favourable weather, there is every chance of the vessel being refloated, but unfortunately for those in charge of the salvage operations the elements have greatly handicaped the work. Old residents of Alexandria who are qualified to express an opinion, and who are interested in the wreck, tell us that it is quite possible that the wind will veer round to blow from land, in which case the chances of success would be considerably enhanced. No cargo has yet been discharged, beyond the two hundred tons jettisoned before the arrival of the salvage steamer, and the opinion has been expressed to us by one well-informed on nautical points that the vessel probably now contains as mach water as previous to the commencement of pumping operations.

div.head: Attaok on Shawleh.
div.p: Last Friday afternoon at Port Tevfik, native seaman, belonging to one of the mooring boats, being drunk, was wrestling in the avenue with another fellow; and when the shawish on duty ordered him to stop, he turned round on him, and knocked him down insensible with a foreible blow of his fist on the side of his face
The shawish was at once conveyed to the hospital for treatment, while the w ilant jumped into the Canal, and with great difficulty was taken out of the water, and carried to the police station.

div.head: Suez Fire Brigade.
div.p: Last night at 11 o'clock a fire broke out in a block of native houses, situated behind the Kbedivia Mail Line Office. Thanks to the prompt assistance given by the fire brigade, the conflagration was quickly extinguished, though not until considerable damage was done. The Govenior of Suez, Ibrahim Bey Halmi, and the chief of the Police, Mr. N. De Touris personally directed the operations and are to be congratulated on their efforts in controlling the fire.

div.head: SOME INTERESTING STATISTICS
div.p: The Board of Trade Journal" in an interest ing article on British Trade with Africk, draws attention to the striking increase in the trade of the United Kingdom with Egypt during the
at four year in 1902 this amounted in value to £20,034,000, while last year it had increased by nearly six million, the total being £26,011,000.

During this period the imports from Egypt into the United Kingdom have time from £13,765,000 to £16,858,000, and the exports to Egypt from the United Kingdom from £6,269,000 to £9,153,000. The increase in the value of the imports is chiefly due to the higher price of Egyptian cotton, the total value of the imports of which one from £9,938,000 in 1902 to £18,278,000 in 1906, forming in the latter year more than 78 per cent of the total value of the imports. Of the remaining 22 per cent, over 13 per cent. is accounted for by the trade in cotton seed, which, after declining for two years, has continued the upward movement recorded for 1905, the imports being valued at £2,333,000 last year as against £2.119,000 in 1905.

div.head: EXPORTS TO EGYPT
div.p: Heavy shipments of corn continue to be made to Egypt from this port. Since the Moss S.S. liners no longer pay their visits here at regular frequent intervals, a large share of the Island produce destined for Egyptian ports has been shipped by the weekly mail boat which of láte has had very full cargoes, A good number of cattle and sheep were put on board the Limassol S.S. "Lefkosia" last week, and we understand that a good deal of stoff could not find room. At Paphos a stift S.W. breeze was blowing at the time this vessel called, and owing to the state of the sea and the exposed nature of the anchorage it was not possible to load the merchandise which was awaiting shipment there. Indeed a considerable difficulty was experienced in landing and taking on board the passengers at that port.

A number of sponge boats from the Greek Islands are still here. They appear to have had a good season. The Cyprus sponge boats have also been here and at Paphos and report having had successful hauls. The death of one of the divers occurred early in the season, but otherwise there have been no mishaps or casualties.

The number of prisoners detained both in the Central Prison and at the various police stations in the Island is exceptional small. It is to be hoped that the satisfactory inference may correctly be drawn from this state of things, that crime is diminishing in Cyprus.
It is reported that an unprecedently large number of gun licences are being issued this season.
A good many cases of malaria have occurred this summer. Almost every large town has suffered from it, and many villages also, but fever has not been of a serious nature.
The local Press announces that Mr. Crawford Noble has been appointed an Assistant Forest officer. He is expected to arrive early in October.
Mr. George Harvey, Government Veterinary Surgeon is about to be transferred from Nicosia to this town.
General Bullock arrived last week from Egypt on a visit of inspection, and proceeded to Troodos. Mr. Fraser, of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers accompanied him as A.D.C.
Mrs. Bucknill, wife of the new King's Advocate, also came, and, with her husband, has gone into camp on Troodos.

div.head:
NEW ALHAMBRA THEATRE
FRENCH COMEDY TROOP
div.p: On the whole the acting of the above company is distintly good, though the talent is unevenly distributed in several cases important parts being filled in amateurish manner, so obvious in awkward movement and attempted abandon. But the stars quite atone for the lesser brilliancy of the satellites, and in particular Mlle Norbert is altogether charming Her clear enunciation, perfect deportment, and mastery of the subtle possibilities of Freoch dialogue and repartee are lessons in the histrionic art. The French stage largely depends on prointed conversation and little setion, both of which characteristics are not tolerated by our own adience. But then convertion with the French is not M with us neity, but fine art. With the additional advantage of its language, there is exceptional opportunity for word play on the gamut of human emotions. As regards the main character MM. Charpentier and Angely are good, but in common with the rest of the company mumble their words, and the Alhambras has not the acoustic properties for drawing room tone. They are rather stagey and occasionally far too much of the novelette type. The repertoire is extensive and contains excellent pieces. "L'Abbe Constantin" in particular being both well played and staged. The porta contain the usual characters of French comedy and drama, the inevitable Abbé, soldier, and vacuous son. The repartee was extremely good and the situations excellent. French playwrights excel in their situations. They know so well how to give the crux of the matter in a word, a look, a gesture! The audiences are fair, and decidedely appreciative

div.head: INVESTMENT IN EGYPT.
SOURCE OF WEALTH.
div.p: (Continued.) As cotton and its future is of each vital importance to Egypt's welfare, let us next consider the probabilities as regards (a) its quality, (b) ita quantity, and (c) its value, during the next few years. In respect to quality, the Government takes every possible means of encouraging the farmers to grow food seed. The Agricultural Society yearly distributes tens of thousands of bushels of selected cotton seed at cost price, and when the present is temporarily short of ready money the Agrlicultural Bank furnishes goods seed as an advance at resonable rates. Care is taken also that the seed supplied is not only, sound, but that it is likewise of those varieties of the cotton plant which, as years of experience have shown, produce the best quality plus the greatest yield per pod. In like manner artificial fertilizers are supplied by the same society, while the Government annually spend large sums in endeavoring to minimise the ravages so often wrought by the ordinary cotton-worm, by the cut-worm (which eats the roots of the young plants), by the boll-worm, and like pests. As an example of the promptness with which this danger is dealt with, I many mention that the report for the week ending June 20 last states that of 4,891 acres (in 121 different villages) found to be infected with the cotton-warm in the Beherah and Dakahlieh provinces 4,382 acres were cleared, and the damage done to the plants was consequently comparatively insignificant.

The quantity of the crop in the future seems assured, for each year more land, chiefly in Upper Egypt has been converted from basin into perennial, and when the new scheme of heightening the Assouan Dam (some 20ft., at a cost of circa £1,500,000) is completed a still greater acreage than at present will come under cultivation and be available for cotton.

The question of the future "price" of cotton is a more delicate one. To make any dogmatic assertion would be imprudent, to prophesy would be equally foolish. Certain considerations, nevertheless, may fittingly be set forth. Taking first the general problem of supply and demand, we find that the world's present supply of cotton is not in excess of the world's demand, and that hitherto as production has increased the consumption of the raw material hus likewise steadily angmented. Probably it would not be far wide of the truth to estimate the world's present consumption of cotton per week at very nearly 300,000 bales (say, 1,500,000 cantars), and the anxiety in Lancashire is not, as a rule, a fear of over-supply, but rather takes the form of the query, "Will there be enough raw material to keep all the spindles running full time?" Secondly, the cotton supply of the world may be divided roughly as follows:--America contributes 22/32 of the whole, the East Indies 6/32, Egypt 3/32, and othercountries the remaining thirty-second part. It is obvious that when America's latge crop is adversely affected by weather or other conditions, Egyptian prices should rise, or, at least, continue firm. Yet it does not always follow that when America's cotton crop in very abundant, values of Egyptian cotton décline. For owing chiefly, and this brings as to our third, point, to that dampness in the atmosphere so prevalent and upiversal in Lower Egypt, Delta cotton is practically without rival in colour and staple perhaps, as regards the small quantity of sea-island cotton cultivated in the group off the mainland of Georgia. Egyptian cotton is the only description absolutely adapted for certain manufactures, though employed in many and the fact is curious that there is a large and new demand for long-staple cotton (this year amounting to some 60,000 cantars) in connection with the manfictite of tyren for automobiles. So the demand for "Egyptian" is constant and increasing, and is not entity dependent on whether the United States produce good or bad crops; and this is very clearly demonstrated by the fact that America herself yearly imports an increasing quantity of Egyptian cotton. Since 1896 such imports into the United States hate augmented by about 33%, and, owing to long staple upland being now rarely grown in America, a few American mills depend almost entirely on the supply from Egypt. Although Egyptian cotton seed of the finest quality has been procured by foreigners, and sown in nearly every cotton-growing country in the world, the product, though excellent, has never, speaking generally, approached, in so far a colour and staple are concerned, the cotton raised in the Delta from precisely similar seed, though it is right to mention that retent attempts to acclimatise Egyptian cotton on the banks of the Indias (in Sinde) are said to have met with some success. Personally, I believe this to be due to the absence in other contrit of that before mentioned dampness so prevalent in the Delta at a critical period of the plant's growth; but whether it is really owing to atmospheric or climatic influences influences, or, as has been held, to some peculiar qualities of the Nile mud soil, is really immaterial, except as a matter of interest to aricultural scientists, so long as the fact remains that the best qualities of Egyptian cotton cannot be grown elsewhere in the same perfection in the Delta. It would be futile to maintain that prices may not fall, all the foregoing favourable confiderations notwithstanding, yet the above data should assist in the formation of a reasonable opinion, and the balance of profitabilty seems to favour the maintenance of fairly high prices under normal circumstances; while under prudent guidance Egypt should undoubtedly, as in her ancient days, be able in years of plenty to make provision for periods less favoured.
(To be continued.)

div.head: EGYPTIAN MARKETS
div.p: In our article a week ago on that very prosperous undertaking, the Egyptian Markets, we gave a brief outline of its position, and the scope of its operations. The favourale view which we then expressed as to its prespects in the future may now he confirmed by the mention of some further considerations, establishing any reader to form a correct judgement as to the soundness of the shares as an investment at to the present time. Not the least conclusive of the evidence to be adduced is the mere fact that, whereas during the past few weeke Egyptian authorities of an industrial nature have almost without exception suffered a severe loss in market value, the shares in Egyptian Markets have been affected to quite a trifing extent, and remain still only slightly below the highest price ever noted for them thronghout their

The reason for this exceptional steadiness in the shares of a company which stand at nearly 50 per cent above par, although they pay the holder rarely 2 per cent. at that price, can only be that they are in the hands of very strong people whose faith in the future of the concern is founded on the most reliable bases, and is not capable of being shaken to any perceptible extent by the storms of advese opinion and the blasts of financial discourage ment which make such wreckage of the weaker speculative ventures. If, in search of reasons to account for this phenomenon, we look to evidences derived from the country itself, there is no difficulty in finding plenty of them. In the first place, the people for whom this company caters, and upon whose custom it thrives, are the indigenous natives of Egypt - the fellaheen. And to these rustics, whose views and whose interests do not extend far beyond their own paddy-fields or cotton or sugar plantations, the

in land or shares have no meaning and no importance. Many of them do not even know what is meant by bank, but bury their savings in the ground. The markets--of which there are no less than 120 in Upper and Lower Egypt--are the one publie institution in which they believe, and where they transact business. It is needless to say that this business has been growing just as fast during the late bad times in Alexandria as it did in the days when the Levantines and Greeks and other clever people in the cities were running riot in extravagant speculations. Then, again, the agriculturist has been, in his slow way, imbibing a confidence and a feeling of reliance upon the British company which has brought within easy reach of him the

for his cattle and other commodition. This will be greatly fortified and augmented when the Markets have become the sole agents for the two important companies which work the salt monopoly. The great advantage that will accrue from this agency may be roughly estimated when it is remembered that the same staff which is now employed in managing the Markets will be able without extra expense, to undertake the duties connected with the salt tunde, which is important an item in the financial budget in Egypt as it is in India. Moreover the farmer in the rich valley of the Nile, as well as in the less fertile fields further removed from the river, is fast learning what benefits may result to him from
The Employment of Nitrates.

The trade in this commodity, which has been secured by the company, will be one of the largest and most increasingly remuneractive branches of its business. If now we endeavour to find any element of danger or risk to which the company's interests are exposed, we small have a difficulty in finding it, except in the cattle disease, which in the years 1903 and 1904 seriously interfered with operations, and practically rendered the Market unremuneractive for some months. The situation has now been altogether changed. The disease although not altogether eliminated, has been localised, and
Precautionary Measures

have now been taken whereby it will be rendered impossible for it to spread from one district to another. If the objection is taken that the company's concession will expire in 1938, when the shares will have no further value as an investment, the reply is that the very first charge of the annual income is the contribution to a sinking fond as such sum as will enable the shareholders to receive back their capital intact when the concession comes to end. The details of the arrangement by which this simple result is noured we must explain at another time.
"Daily Report"

div.head:
ST. MARK'S. AlEXANDRIA
APPOINTMENT OF ASSISTANT CHAPLAIN
div.p: The Rev. S. C. Barmby, B.A., late Curate of Christ Church, Westminster, and now Chaplain at St. George's Hospital, London, has accepted the post of Assistant Chaplain at St. Mark's

Mr. Barmby graduated at Durham University and spent a year at Leed's Clergy School. He was ordained deacon 1889 and priest 1892. After holding a curacy for six years at Frodsham, another curacy at St. Olave's, Stoke Newington, he went to South Africa as Acting Chaplain to the Forces during the war. Mr Barmby is expected to arrive at the end of October.

TRIAL LESSON FREE
Modifications in Postal Arrangements consequent on the International Congress at Rome in 1900, which will come into-force on the 1st October next.

div.head: LETTERS
div.p: The tax on letters originating in Egypt and the Sudan for Abroad will be:
1. Five milliemes for every 20 grammes, or fraction thereof for Great Britain and Ireland and all British Colonies, Possessions and Protecterats with the exception of Newfoundland.
2. Five milliemes for every 20 grammes,or fraction thereof, for Italy, Eritrea and Benadir.
3. Ten missiles for the first 20 grammes and 6 milliemes for every extra 20 grammes for all Countries in the Postal Union not mentioned in Paragraphs 1 and 2
4. Ten milliemes for every 20 grammes, or fraction therof for Countires not in the Postal Union, viz :--Abyssinia, China (Interior) Afghanistan, New Hebrider, North East and North West Rhodesia.

div.head: POST-CARDS
div.p: Cards bearing the inscription "POST CARD" will be in the same category as "printed matter" provided that they fufil the conditions laid down for such matter. Shold they, however, not fulfil these conditions they will be considered as ordinary Post Cards and treated as such, otherwise, according to the regulations in force for Post Cards, they will be taxed as letters.

div.head: BUSINESS PAPERS & SAMPLES
div.p: Letter will post carde which have attained their primary object will be considered as commercial papers. Single keys, french cut flowers, tubes of serum and pathologic articles rendered inocuons by treatment or packing will be considered as samples

div.head: REPLY COUPONS
div.p: Reply coupons will enable the sender of a letter to transmit the cost of reply to the addressess. These reply coupons will be sold at 11 milliemes each.

These coupons can be exchanged in all Countries to which this Service extends for cash or postage stamps to the value of 25 Centimes. Information as to the Countries which are admitted to this Service can be obtained from any post office.

div.head: FOREIGN MONEY ORDERS
div.p: The tax on Foreign Money Orders will be as follows:--
1. Ten milliemes for every or frutice there for Money Orders addressed to Great Brital and Ireland, all British Colonies, Pressions al Protectorates, and Russia.

2. Ten milliemes for every £:2 or fraction plus 5 milliems as a supplementary charge for exchange (total 15 milliemes) for Money Orders addressed to those Countries included in the International Convention.

div.head: INSCRIPTIONS ON MONEY ORDERS.
div.p: Money Orders which bear an inscription written in pencil will not be accepted.

div.head: PARCELS
div.p: The tax on paroels not exceeding 1 Kilo: in weight will be reduced for certain Countries.
1. Parcels of which the wires are written in pencil will not be accepted for transmission.

2. All parcels for abroad must be packed in some manner as to ensure the safety and preservation of the contente during transport. They must also be sealed with wax, lead or some such substance, which seals must bear the imprint of some special design.
Customs declarations must accompany all parcels for abroad and must show the exact value of the contents of such parcels in order to facilitate the, collection of export and quay dues (if any).

Communications relative to parcels sent may be written on Despath Notes. This facility however does not extend to Despatch Notes of parcels addressed to Great Britain and, Ireland and British Colonies, with the exeption of British India.

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENT OP RECEIPT AND PAYMENT
div.p: The sender of registered or insured article a parcel or a money order will be able to obtain an Acknowledgement of Receipt by the addreśsee from the Post Office of payment of 10 milliemes at the time of posting

div.head: OTHER SERVICES
div.p: Notice is also given to the effect that the following services, which have not undergone much alterations by the Postal Congress, are undertaken by the Post Office.
By means of this service the contents at letters and boxes can be insured according to their value, with a maximum of 10,000 francs

The Post Office will undertake to present any bill, draft etc. to a debtor for collection of the amount. In case this cannot be obtained however no action will be taken by the Post Office against the person.

Subscriptions for newspapers published in Egypt and the Sudan as well as Austria-Hungary, Belgium, Great Britain and Ireland, Germany, Italy, Switzerland and the United States of America, can be taken out at the Post Office

4. Identity CertificatesIn order to minimise the difficulties often experienced by the Public in obtaining postal matter or money orders addressed to them, identity certificates can be obtained from Post Office at the rate of 20 milliemes each.
These certificates hold good for the following Countries :--
Argentine Republic, Algeria, Bulgaria, Chili, France, Greece, Italy, Luxemburg, Mexico, Portugal and Portugese Colonies, Roumania, Switzerland, Tunis, Turkey and Venezuela
General Pont Ofice.
30913-3*-1 Egypt, 16th September 1907.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication un emplacement gazonné dans le Grand Jardin Nousha de la superficie de 3 feddans environ pour café pablic et restaurant
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau des Pares et Plantations où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés
Les offres devront être adresses sous pli cacheté Monsieur le Vice President de la Municipalité avant le ler Octobre prochain.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: Soumission pour la location de café au Grand Jardin Nouzha
Le cautionnement préva au cahier des charges, devra être versé an Service de la Comptabilité générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le ler Octobre de 9 h. à midi.
Toate offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions cids Mr Snartte
Si les offres ne sont satisfaisantes, la Municipalité n'est pas tenue de les accepter.
Alexandrie le 14/9/07.
Le Vice-President. 30916-3-1
(signé) Dr SMS

div.head:
THE CASABLANCA SITUATION.
ARREST OF UJDA NOTABLES.
SULTAN LEAVES FOR RABAT.

div.p: Four Ujda notables have been arrested and brought to Lallamarnia. They are charged with carrying on an anti-French propaganda among the tribes.(Reuter)
The French balloon ascended yesterday. The entire country was reported to be clear of Arabs.(Reuter)

Everything is quiet. The troops are resting. Two camps, Titmellel and Merchich, are reported at 25 kilometres to the south. If the peace emissaries have not arrived by noon to-day, Kasba Fedala will be bombarded, and General Drude's operations will be vigoronsly recommenced. (Havas)
The Mehallas are now camped beyond the reach of cannon. The Governor of the town yesterday paid a visit of courtesy to General Drnde. (Havas)
The Moorish Minister of War bas agreed to organise police without delay, as provided and stipulated by the Algeciras Act. The Sultan Abdul Aziz left Suez on the 12th for Rabat. (Havas)
The Sultan has left Fez for Rabat where he is expected to arrive on 21st instant. It is reported that Mulay Hafid is also going to Rabat with 30,000 followers.
General Drude reports that a prolonged armistice of 24 hours has been granted at the request of the tribesmen, the majority of whom are in favour of peace. (Reuter)

The Press attacks the naval administration for the stranding of the "Standart." The "Slove" declares the incident to be worse than the Tshushima one. It stigmatizes the administration's ignorance of home waters as criminal. (Reuter)

div.head:
ENGLAND IN EGYPT.
APPEAL TO LIBERAL PARTY.

div.p: Mustapha Pasha Kamel, in a letter addressed to Sir H. Campbell Bannerman, declares that 25 years have passed since England promised to evacuate Egypt. The Liberal party in England must decide whether Egypt's independence is to come with Liberal help or without (Reuter)

div.head:
THE WELLMAN EXPEDITION.
ABANDONED FOR A YEAR.

div.p: Mr. Wellman's airship has been rescued in a glacier intact. The expedition has been abandoned for a year. (Reuter)

More cheerful letters have been received from Sir H. Maclean stating that He has been allowed certain comforts. El Raisu'i's demands as presented to Great Britain are still impossible, but he is expected to rapidly moderate them. (Reuter)

The "Times" comments on the danger of the Hagne Conference seeking to hide failure by nominally sanctioning a number of showy ill-considered propositions in order to impress an uninstructed public. It cites the case of the Prize Court and says that the reason for which Russia and Japan provisionally withheld their assent was weighty. It urges that England should follow the example of her sagacious ally Japan and take time to minutely study the Prize Court scheme before committing herself. (Reuter)

div.head:
GREECE AND TURKEY.
DRAMA PATRIARCHATE RECALLED

div.p: In consequence of the urgent and frequent representations of the Porte, the Patriarchate has recalled the Metropolitan of Drama who, it is alleged, was implicated in the Greek band movement.(Reuter)
The Abyssinian mission has arrived bere from Dresden.(Reuter)
The Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine has presented a medal to Professor Looss of Cairo.(Reuter)
The ex-Grand Vizier, Mushir-el-Dowleh, is dead. (Reuter)
A council order has been gazetted establishing a legislative council for Cyprus, to be composed of 12 elective and 6 non elective members. (Reuter)
The Royal Irish Yacht Club has challenged the American Cup on behalf of Sir T. Lipton, for September 1908.(Reuter)

President Fallieres has reprieved the mur. derer Soleilland in spite of the popular clamour for his execution. This signifies the abolition of the death penalty in France Police are guarding the Elysée fearing a hostile demonstration. (Reuter)
A Quebec to Boston express has collided with a goods train : 17 persons have been killed and 40 injured. (Reuter)
Georgiades Effendi, the new Governor, has arrived here. He had a cool reception. (Reuter)
The match between the rest of England and Notts at Oval was drawn. (Reuter)

div.head: THE LEBANON EXPERIMENT
div.p: The special correspondent to the Times" writes from Beyrout as follows:--

The nomination of Yusuf Pasha to the Governorship of the Lebanon has not been received with any great enthusiasm in "the Mountain." The fear that the new Governor wonld follow the pro-elerical policy of his father, Franco Nasri Pasha, who governed the Lebanon from 1868 to 1873, had already provoked a demonstration of over 1,500 anti-clericals from the Maronite district of Kesrawan, with a few Druses who, on July 3, appeared in Beirut, and begged the Vali to transmit a petition to the Porte protesting against his appointment. It is quite possible that the petition never reached the Porte; but, however vain their protest, the anti-clericals of what was till recently the most bigoted district in the Maronite territory had at least the satisfaction of showing Beirut that their strength, sedulously minimized by the clergy, was numerically greater than their opponents had dared to admit. Other sections of the population regarded with some anxiety. the appointment of the son of a former Governor, connected by marriage with Naoum Pasha, who preceded the late Muzaffer Pasha as Governor of the province, arguing that the new Mutesarrif was not unlikely to be influenced by the supporters of his father and Naonm Pasha in the appointment and dismissal of functionaries, from the point of view of the numerous placehunters of the Lebanon, the most important of the prerogatives of the Governor of "the Mountain."

The future will show how far these apprehensions are well grounded ; meanwhile Yusuf Pasha will require greater abilities than those with which he is credited, even by his supporters, if he is to make a firm stand against the intrigues of families and factions and the growth of political corruption, which proved too strong for his predecessor. For Muzaffer Pasha's administration this much may be claimed---namely, that it equitably maintained the balance between the various religious secta, each of which was, and is, only too ready to take offence at the slightest encroachment, real or fancied, on its rights as guaranteed by the Organic Law of 1861. Otherwise, it was unsuccessful ; Liberal views and good intentions, personal integrity, tact, and kindliness could not atone for the fatal weakness of will that made the late Governor the pappet of intrigues local, Consular, and domestic and disappointed all who had believed that his early promises of administrative reform would be carried into effect. But whatever may have been urged against Muzaffer Pasha's administation, what ever may be urged in the future against that of Yusuf Pasha, it must be admitted that the position of the Governor of the Lebanon has become far from enviable. Though, perhaps, the most independent of Ottoman officials during his term of office, he is none the less compelled, in view of his eventual return to Constantinople, to avoid all action that may ruffle the susceptibilities or arouse the suspicions of the Sultan. The Great Powers of Europe' through their representatives at Beirut and Constantinople, take a more or less active interest in his administration ; religious rival ries, the intrigues of local notables and of the administrative council, an antiquated Constitution, and an illogical system of local finance hamper his every action. He is, in short, condemned to carry out a most difficult task with the aid of obsolete machinery and with the certainty of interference from without and within.

It may be urged that this is a somewhat cavalier criticism of the results of the experiment of 1860, that since the interference of Europe the Lebanon has enjoyed complete immunity from the disturbances that are endemic in other provinces of the Ottoman Empire, that the Lebanese are themselves mainly to blame for the growing disorganization of the administration, or that, given a strong Governor of the type of Rustem Pasha, all would once more go well in the Mountain." Before replying to these objections it is necessary to give a brief sketch of the physical and social conditions of the province, as far as they have any bearing upon local politics, and of its Constitution according to the modified Organic Law ot 1864.
"THE MOUNTAIN" AND ITS PEOPLE

The province of Lebanon, as defined by the protocols of 1861 and 1864, is not conterminous with the mountain range of that name. It may be roughly described as a strip of mountainous country, bounded on the east by the watershed and on the west by the Mediterranean, averaging some 25 miles in breadth, and extending some 40 miles north and 80 miles south of Beirut, which, with the towns of Tripoli and Sidon, is under direct Ottoman administration. On the eastern slope of the central range of the Lebanon the town and part of the district of Zahleh belong to the province, as does the isolated village of Hurmil, 30 miles northwest of Baalbeck. Except in the neighbourhood of Beirut and in part of the district of Kūra immediately south of Tripoli, the country is simply a succession of stony ridges, projecting westward like ribs from the backbone of the central chain and separated from one another by deep and often precipitous ravines. Save in the low-lying areas that have been mentioned, the country is naturally little suited to agriculture, the whole of the corn crop, planted in the stoniest of soils, being insufficient to supply the needs of the population of the province for three months. The plodding industry of the pesants has covered the billsides with terraces, on which mulberries, vines, and a few other fruits are grown, and sericulture is now the principal, and in many districts almost the only, occapation of the people, the bulk of the ooooons, waste silk, and silk thread exported, to the amount of nearly 25,000 bales during the last three years, from Beirut and Tripoli coming from the Lebanon villages. Some 20 silk spinning mills, few of which employ more than 60 persons, are at work mainly in the central districts of the province. Vines are very generally grown, and some very good wine is manufactured in the neighbourhood of Zahleh. Sheep and goats are fairly numerous, and the latter most destructive to the scanty remnants of the forests which once covered the mountains. Minerals may exist in paying quantities within certain areas, but on this point nothing appears to be definitely known.

The whole configuration of the country makes for political disunion. A village is often nearly a day's journey from its vis-à-vis on the next ridge or on the next but one, only four or five miles away as the crow flies, but separated by precipitous gorges hundreds of feet deep, and perhaps eight or ten miles in length. Religion, here as elsewhere in the Ottoman Empire, the principal cause of political division, has aided nature in accentuating the differences between the various sections of what seems to have been originally a fairly homogeneous population. There are certainly two or three general racial types that may be found, at times in the same family, all over Syria; but it is equally certain that some Europeans and many natives who possess a thorough knowledge of the country and its people can usually distinguish between a Maronite and a Greek Catholic, a Moslem and a Druse. The majority of the religions and sects of Syria are represented in "the Mountain." Isolated groups of Moslems, both Sannis and Metwali Shiahs, with a few mountain Beduin, occur in the southern district of Shaf, near Zahleh, and in Kesrawan, while isolated Hormil is mainly inhabited by Metwalis. Shof is the centre of the Lebanon Druses, who are also represented in the central district of Metn and in Jezzin in the extreme south. To turn to the Christian sects, the northern districts, with the important exception of Kura, & Greek Orthodox stronghold, are almost entirely inhabited by Maronites, Zahleh is predominantly Greek Catholic, and in the southern provinces the sects are mixed, the Maronites being rather more numerous than the Orthodox Greeks, while small groups of Protestants occur bere and there, usually in the neighbourhood of mission stations. No census having been taken since 1862, it impossible to give more than an approximate estimate of the present population of the province. According to the best-informed autborities, tbe Maronites number about 220,000, the Druses 60,000, and the Orthodox Greeks some 45,000, the balance of from 60,000 to 70,000 souls being mainly composed of Greek Catholics and Sunni and Metwali Moslems,

Like most mountaineers, the peasants, who constitute the great majority of the population, are a decidedly attractive race. Physically strong, well-made, and often good looking, they are mentally a shrewd, sharp-witted folk, with an intelligence that is more Buropean-that is, more ratiocinative and controlled to a greater extent by conscious logical processes-than that of the average uneducated or half-educat ed Egyptian, whose pind never seems to have room for more than a few fixed quasi-instinctive ideas which he may attempt to defend, but at which he seldom seems to arrive, with the aid of reason. Politically unstable and inclined to petty intrigue, as opportunist as most of their neighbours, still somewhat deficient in moral courage, regarding local affairs too often from & sectarian or personal standpoint, their civic qualities are still rudimentary, though better developed than those of certain other Oriental races. In enterprise, courage, self-respect, and freedom from petty crime they are far superior to the Egyptian; but what most impresses the visitor from Egypt is their respect for women, whose influence on the family life of the people is very marked both among Christians and Druses. A girl may travel alone through the most solitary districts of "the Mountain" without fear of harm, and per contra the sight of a laden woman staggering along in the dust behind her lord, who rides comfortably on an ass, common enough in the Nile Valley, is extremely rare, if not unknown, among the Lebanese.

It would be tedious and unprofitable to describe the civil war of 1860, which was simply the culmination of an ancient quarrel between the closely-knit Druse community led by the powerful families of Jumblat and Arslan and the less cohesive Maronites, directed and often led by their numerous and powerful clergy. The conflict was marked by numerous terrible incidents, such as the sack of Zahleh and the massacre at Dêr el Kamar ; but it may be noted that the Druses, if ruthless in battle, abstained from inflicting any insult or harm on women and children, the more brutal outrages that disgraced the struggle being the work of Turkish troops and of bands of fanatical Moslems from the vilayets of Beirut and Damascus. The civil war and the savage antiChristian outbreaks in the vilayets caused the intervention of the Powers, which resulted in granting of administrative autonomy to the Lebanon. Though deprived of its natural outlets to the sea and shorn of some of its most fertile areas, the new province secured the inestimable advantage of being guaranteed against direct Turkish interference or administration. Its constitution, as framed in the Organic Law of 1861-6, its revised version of 1864, may be very briefly summarized.

The province is administered by an irremovable Christian Governor appointed for a period of five years and directly dependent upon the Porte. He possesses full administrative powers, save in loyal finance, is responsible for the collection of taxes and the maintence of public order, and the appointment of administrative and executive officials, including Judges of first instance and appeal. He also convokes the council known as the Mejlis el Idarah. This body is composed of 12 representatives of the seven administrative districts, or kaima kamliks, of "the Mountain" chosen from the dominant seot or seots of each district. Thus Kara is represented by an Orthodox Greek, Zahleh by a Greek Catholic, Shaf by a Druse and a Moslem. The members are elected by the sheikhs of the villages for a period of six years, four members retiring every two years with the right to re-election. The functions of the council are consultative and financial; the latter are of very considerable importance, for the Mejlis el Idareh is, to all intents and purposes, an inde pendent department of finance, solely responsible for the framing of the Budget, the imposition of taxes, infine, for the entire control of the revenue and expenditure. In financial matters its word is law, and, though Naoum Pasha shortly after his appointment as Ambassador obtained the permission of the Porte and the Powers to dismiss every member of the council on the ground of its improper interference with elections, there are obvious reasons against the frequent adoption of so drastic a measure. The administrative unit is the Nah ieh, or village commune, under a sheikh elected by the inhabitants, dependent on the mudirieh, or subdistrict, which is in turn dependent on the kaymakamlik, or administrative district. The kaimakans are appointed by the Governor, the Medjis by the Governor in theory on the recommendation of the kaimakam. The electors of the Mejlis el Idareh are the sheikhs of the village communes of each district, who also possess the power to try petty cases of misdemeanour, &c, and to impose fines not exceeding 200 piastres, their judicial functions resembling those of justices of the peace. Crimes are dealt with by the Courts of first instance and appeal, in which the principle of representation by communities is followed in all "mixed" cases--that is, cases in which the parties are of a different religion or sect.

div.head: A CASE OF INTEREST TO WOMEN
div.p: 15, Milier Street
Coatbridge Scotland.

It is many years ago now since I was first taken with kidney trouble. It began with a dull, grinding pain in the small of my back, bat after a while there were sharp, sudden pangs of pain, which nearly brought me down, and these were followed by other symptoms of kidney trouble, especially gravel, and great pain in passing water.

During pregnancy, the pains were much harder to bear, and just before the birth of my last child there was complete stoppage, which alarmed me very much. My limbs swelled up, and my eyesight was affected. I used to get such pains in the head that I hardly knew what to do with myself.

Doctors and medicine alike failed to give me any relief, but at last I have found help in Doan's Backache Kidney Pills. They have been & real blessing to me, and I will always say 80; nothing has ever given me such ease. Doan's Pills have strengthened my back, and have made me feel better in many ways. Indeed, I can truthfully say that by their occasional use I keep in better health than I was for years before.

Some months later, Mrs. Foster said: "I was grateful for the good Doan's Pills did me when I told you about it some months ago, but how much more grateful I feel now that I can tell you it is a lasting cure! There has been no return of my serious kidney and bladder disorders since Kidney relieved me.
"It is my wish that you make this widely known, so that others suffering as I used to, may know how to get well."

Such distressing symptoms as irregular action of the heart, violent, thumping beats, poor circulation of the blood, cold hands and feet, strained breathing, fainting fits, and dizzy spells, are generally to be traced to the kidneys; seldom is there anything the matter with the heart itself, and when the kidneys are cured the heart troubles also will be cured. If, however these disorders are neglected, dropsical symptoms, such as puffy eyes and swollen ankles and limbs, will appear, and the body will gradually fill with water.
Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T.per box.
